And there's the $30 activation fee and the old 'by-the-way', that unlimited data plan you were grandfathered into no longer applies. I now get 2 GB and additional fees apply if that is exceeded. But, they assured me that after the initial bill with the activation fee, my Family Plan bill would remain the same. I'll update that if that turns out to be false.

reviewTitle: This phone is awesome. I'm an android girl (NOT an I girl)

reviewText: I tried the 16 MP camera in daylight and it was very crisp. Big chunk of data if you upload using other than WiFi but the one thing that is consistent about Verizon is you're lucky to get an edge signal here. Downloads that size would crash and burn using cell service. Yea, it bright red 4G LTE on the map but not on the phone. Unfortunately, nobody has ever commented on how good their carrier's signal is here. Scary since there are a lot of boaters on the bay who think the phone is a good alternative to VHF radio. On the other hand, a surprise came when I noticed how far I was from the house and still connected to my home network. Simply amazing.

The one glitch I see is that the weather reported by the phone is incorrect. The location and time are correct but that's a glitch I have yet to figure out. It'll consistently refresh with the wrong information. Maybe it's just telling me what I want to hear.
reviewTitle: A great phone!  More of an evolution than a revolution.

reviewText: I've set the fingerprint reader to unlock the phone and it works but sometimes takes a few tries. There is the option of using patterns and passwords instead. No bells and whistles omitted on this phone. I could live without the cover that protects the USB and HDMI connectors and expect that will be the one thing that breaks. Just a hunch.
reviewTitle: Thank goodness for this beautiful phone! bye bye iPhone HELLO GALAXY S5

reviewText: There is a slot for an additional SD card and the one from my old Droid now lives there. Plenty of memory. Also, the battery is replaceable and that's a big deal to me. Needs no special tools like the aftermarket kits to open the Motorola and Apple devices. Speaking of which, someone was returning the new Apple phone while I was buying the Samsung. Don't know why but not a good sign. A lot of words for a phone I've had for just a day but it's a lot of phone.

The display on the phone is beautiful and I love the ultra power saving mode for when I'm at work. The USB 3 charging port is a little annoying to fiddle with, and improving it would have been as simple as putting the attached edge of the port cover on the opposite side from the micro USB part, which I use most often for charging. Also, on this and other Galaxy phones (between me and my husband we've had the 3, 4, and now 5) sometimes the time zone switches for no reason while the phone is idle. They really need to fix this, I thought it was just because our phones were getting old but I've only had this a month. Why should I have to also buy an alarm clock to get up on time?

reviewText: This phone is pretty sweet.. i switched from a s3 and fell in love with it.  Problem is the Sprint network.  You CANNOT use the phone (voice) with data (internet) at the same time.  What does this mean?  If you are using the GPS and you get a call the GPS will drop.  IF you are on the phone and need to look at an email, you cant.  If you want to look up something on the internet  while talking on the phone you cant.  This is finally the straw that broke this camels back.. I purchased this phone through best buy and then three days later took it back to BB and returned it.  I have left Sprint and went to Verizon where you CAN talk and surf at the same time.  Sprints says they will have this feature once they update to the Spark network but that it will take a while to reach all areas.. much like it did for 4g I have been with sprint for over 10 years now and they are always behind.  I will miss unlimited data but I still have 2gigs to play with unlimited text unlimited talk at about the same price as before.

reviewTitle: Samsung Galaxy S5 is a Very Useful Tool for Modern Life

reviewText: This is my first smartphone, and I am very pleased with it. The screen and the phone are somewhat larger than most smartphones, so carrying it on my belt is taking a bit of getting use to it; however I love its capabilities, and the electronics and software seem to be very stable. The camera does a nice job. I have had very little problem with the fingerprint scanner locking feature, except when my finger is wet, and then I can just enter the alternative password. With a dry finger I can unlock the phone probably 80% of the time on the first try. After an initial failure I can almost always get the phone unlocked using additional attempts at the finger scan. I like the fact that I can add memory to it, up to 128 GBytes. Being that it is an Android phone, there is a large variety of apps available. My favorite is Google Maps (comes preloaded). It is turn-by-turn navigation which also shows real-time traffic information. That is a real time-saver. Another reason I chose this smartphone is that it was designed to be water-resistant, as I spend a good amount of time on and around water.
love my phone
reviewTitle: Nice modern phone with Great Features and Up-to-Date Hardware

reviewText: What's great about it: The amount of value they pack into this phone is truly incredible
What's not so great: Call quality is no worse than other phones, but still needs work; sound output is too low and has one very irksome trait
Everything you could want in a cell phone and more is here. The Samsung Galaxy S5 is awe-inspiring. So let's get into it.

First, the screen. While I am getting a little annoyed by how large cell phones are getting, I see the need for it. The picture quality is superb! But seen on a smaller screen, the quality would not shine through. I've always hated viewing videos on my cell phone, but the S5 does a great job of making me miss my laptop less. And games are more enjoyable too! Photos are so clear it's mindboggling. No cons here.
Discussing the processor and other "brain" components is boring, so suffice it to say that the S5 is very fast and multitasks very well, without being a drain on the battery. Which brings me to...

Love love love this phone. I have been an iPhone user for years and needed a change. I grabbed this phone and have been more than happy with all the features and ways to customize. I will not be going back to an iPhone anytime soon!

I love this phone. I recently just upgraded to this from an iPhone 4S and it is leaps and bounds better and more efficient. The battery is spectacular and the mechanics of the phone itself are really great. The 4S was my first smartphone and this is my second. Never again will I go back to an iPhone.

reviewTitle: You can spend more on a phone... But you won't get more bang for your buck than with an S5!

reviewText: After using a the original Droid RAZR for two years, it was safe to say I was looking for an upgrade in the battery department. With S5 unlike other phones in addition to a big battery, you get one that can be replaced! This became an issue with my RAZR as I use my phone more than any other device I own (Windows laptop, Windows tablet, and Android tablet). Having the option after one year of heavy use to replace the battery will be a refreshing change.

They always say the best camera is the one you have with you. Actually compared to several 100 dollar point and shoots the S5 is just a better camera altogether. If you own an S5 and are shopping for a standard non-enthusiast grade digital camera... Save your money and use the S5. As an amateur photographer with DSLR's and an enthusiast grade large sensor compact with manual control that is saying something. I have yet to take an image and send it to a photo printer but from looking at them on HD screens I am super impressed. Focusing is fast and low light photos turn out unexpectedly good. This is a camera phone not a APC-S sensor DSLR.

The performance for streaming videos and using Slacker is impressive. I guess 2 gigs of ram and quadcore power never hurt! I am not a big app user but do surf the Web a lot and use news/business apps the S5 never disappoints.

Build quality, yes the S5 is still plastic but it never manages to feel cheap. The back cover is comfy in your hand and silver bezel look nice all in all a well put together phone. Think Honda Accord/Toyota Camry when I comes to build quality and you will get the idea.

reviewTitle: This is an awesome phone. I've never had any problems with it

reviewText: This is an awesome phone.  I've never had any problems with it.  It's super fast and responsive.  The screen resolution is excellent and it takes better pictures than my FIL's $1,900 Sony camera.

I do have one gripe about what I consider to be an internal design flaw.  In the event of a relatively low drop from about 3 ft directly on it's front my friend had the S5 screen go blank.  It wouldn't respond to touch and was completely blank.  He asked me to look at it since it already had a small crack in in the corner of the screen and he couldn't get it warrantied.  You cannot access the display connectors on these phones from the back.  You have to remove the screen.  Using a hotplate, I warmed the display and gently separated the screen from the body.  I found that the display connector had come unplugged from the drop.  I plugged it back in and the display was working again.

Why in the world would Samsung make a phone where the connector is inaccessible like this and where there's enough space for it to pop free!!!  A simple piece of foam on the connector or the back of the screen would completely solve this issue.

A quick search shows several others having this same issue.  Some were able to get warranty coverage while others had to pay almost $200 to get them fixed.  It's really a simple repair that took 10 minutes.

I live in Alabama and I am on the Sprint network.  Historically,  I have been an HTC customer.  In July,  I upgraded to the HTC M8.  Sleek phone and great updates.  But I couldn't talk and use internet connection simultaneously without being connected to WIFI.  That included using apps that required internet connection.  My service was also horrible especially at home.  HTC said it was the network and Sprint said the phone did have issues interfacing with their network but this was due to the manufacturer switching from the dual antenna to a single antenna.  I got a new HTC M8 and the same thing occurred.  I was told I was the only customer with this complaint.  At this point, I was three weeks into my purchase and I needed a phone.  So I reluctantly switched to the Samsung S5.  I love HTC so didn't really want to switch.  I don't like the case.  Phone looks flimsy.  Yes great device with great features but my concern is the service.  Once again, I have a phone that cannot talk and use the Internet simultaneously without being connected to the WiFi.  Single antenna. Great at home since I have WiFi but what about when I am on the go.  I have to disconnect my call and then I can use apps (that require Internet connection) or just to send an email.  My service is still poor especially at home even with the signal booster that sprint provided.  I also have 5g home network provided via charter.  My new Samsung 5 phone can't connect to it.  It connects to 2g just like my old laptop and Samsung tablet that I purchased 2 years ago. I don't know if its the phone,  the interface with the network,  or just the Sprint network.  This has been my experience and I think you should do your homework in your coverage area before you buy either the HTC M8 or Samsung S5 especially if you are in Alabama and Sprint is your carrier.  I didn't have this problem with my HTC Evo and neither of my four household members have this problem and we are all on Sprint and they use HTC Evo  and Apple 4.

reviewText: I am very satisfied with my Samsung Galaxy S5. Unlike many other smartphones, it is water-resistant and contains its own Integrated Mobile Health Partner (S Health). S Health has proven to contain very accurate nutrition information on a vast amount of foods. It also possesses a heart rate detector and a pedometer, both of which can be very useful to any health-conscious individual. The phone has a very large and beautiful display but still weighs a mere 5.12 ounces. The camera on this smartphone is impeccable. I also like that you can transfer your entire iTunes library to the phone using Google Play. There is no need to download a new media player and purchase everything again. Other reviews state that the plastic on the back of the phone is a drawback but I disagree. Glass phones break very easily but I have dropped this phone multiple times without any surface damage being done. It is a considerably sturdy phone. Lastly, the S5's battery life is nothing to overlook. The advertisements state that the battery will last through 29 hours of talk time. I have personally experienced an instance showing how great the phone keeps its charge when I took it on a four hour car trip and streamed music online the entire time without losing more than 20% of the battery. After the battery dies completely, it only takes an hour and a half to charge back to 100%.

Even though I highly recommend this phone to everyone, there is one very minor drawback. When setting up the phone you must create a Gmail account. This isn't an operational flaw but more of an inconvenience to the user. You now have to memorize another email address and password.
Overall, this phone is worth the price tag. I plan on keeping it for a very long while.

The fingerprint sensor is a bit annoying though. You have to scan by sliding your finger over the home button, and more perpendicular your finger movement to the home button is, the easier it can be recognized. Not a easy thing with one hand, but with a little practice I was able to get around 50% success rate.
The heart rate sensor is not very accurate but I didn't expect it to be. What I like the least is the cover of charging port. It's a trade-off to make the phone waterproof of course.

If you want a phone that can break and when and when/if it does, there is no guarantee you can get it replaced, than this is the phone for you! I can talk about all the things on this phone that would be good features, but what does it matter if the phone is broken. What does it matter that the phone is supposed to be "water resistant" YOU CANNOT PUT THIS PHONE IN WATER!!!. If you close the phone properly and water still gets in, they will tell you that it was still your fault that it doesn't work. Because there in unfortunately and conveniently almost no way to prove that the phone stopped working due to faulty merchandise. I bought one of these and through my warranty plan replaced it for $200.00 when my first phone broke due to water damage. Then I got a second one, of which I had for about 3 days, before it broke too. that phone broke when I went swimming. I was in shallow water, and for a very short amount of time. I made sure that everything was closed securely on this phone before I went swimming due to previous experience. When this phone stopped working, I took it to a certified Samsung repair store. The phone failed the pressure test, proving that the faulty merchandise was in fact not "water resistant at all" they also said that the corrosion in the phone was irreparable. When I called corporate with these findings from their OWN store. They said it was not SAMSUNG POLICY to replace THEIR phones even the faulty ones. That replacement can ONLY be done through your phone service provider. EVEN THOUGH THE PHONE WAS ONLY IRREPAIRABLE BASED ON THEIR FAULTY MERCHANDISE TO BIGIN WITH! We tried going through our service provider to return this phone. They wanted us to give them another $200. We would not agree to this! We decided to cancel our service completely and go with another phone service. NO one wanted to give us a working phone, or our money back! They sent us a faulty phone and offered NO GARANTEE. This phone can and will sometimes break in water. IT IS NOT a  WATERPROOF PHONE! They will not  replace it should it become irreparable, EVEN IF IT IS THEIR FAULT!!  Who wants to spends hundreds of dollars on any phone without any kind of guarantee the phone will work. IT IS SMASUNGS POLICY TO NOT STAND BY THEIR PRODUCTS. I am never buying anything Samsung again. AND not just because I am angry with how they "resolved" my issue. But also because I am concerned that I will have to deal with SAMSUNGS POOR POLICY and NO GARANTEES again! DONT BUY THIS PHONE!!!

Ultimately I end up either pulling out the battery and putting it back in which seems to work so far, or I have to try to do a hard restart by holding the power button in until it gives up, then turn it back on. With those seeming to work and the occasional tap, I must assume that the issue is an electronics connection on the motherboard or between the video card and display. Another, unrelated(?) issue is I will occasionally get an error message that either the SIM card or SD card are disconnected, but when I check it, it appears to be as snug as possible.

reviewText: After reading the reviews, I was under the impression that the Android OS was more stable than it had been in previous versions of the Galaxy. I had an S4 and liked it well enough, but the constant crashing and lagging led me back to the iPhone. I thought the S5 would be different - I was wrong.
App crashes - happens at least once a day, usually when I move too fast through the app/apps. This never happened on my iPhone...it kept up with me. This phone does not.

Unlocking/Lag - I had it set to password unlock and had to go back to fingerprint because every time I tried to use the PIN number, it would only recognize 2 or 3 of the numbers or take 15 seconds to allow me to input my PIN at all. Fingerprint recognition is not preferred, but it seems to be the only security lock feature that actually works 90% of the time. This is the same type of issues I have with most apps - takes a long time to load and then lags horribly throughout use.

Picture quality - The picture quality is superior to iPhone when it comes to zooming, etc, but the camera app takes forever to open (10-15 seconds) so it's not great for those in-the-moment pics I love to grab.

I replaced my 2-yr old i-phone 4 with the S5.  After about 30 days of use, there is very little I do not like about the S5.  It is actually a much better phone than the old apple.  Bigger and better screen.  Easier to use.  The speaker is not that great though.  Still 5 stars for me.

reviewTitle: Best all-around of the flagship phones on market

reviewText: It's an awesome flagship phone. It's probably the most durable of current flagship phones on the market right now (quality plastic without cheap feel, better than easily broken glass and dented aluminum). The water/dust proofing also contributes to improved durability, and of course it has Gorilla Glass 3. Additionally, the design is very portable and comfortable, despite the size. The performance is top-par, running on multi-core benchmarks as the current fastest. 1080p screen is flawless, for those desiring 4K quality of the LG G3, consider the fact that physiologically you can't really even tell the difference on a phone-size screen between 1080p and quad until it's within 6 inches from your eyes. Touch-wiz is wonderful to use, and the phone is loaded with small conveniences, both in hardware and touchwiz. The small features I have found useful include the IR emitter with smartremote app, heart rate monitor (and S-Health app in general, it's an awesome fitness application), one-hand use, ultra power saving mode (extreme battery life), multi-window, private mode, and the fingerprint lock (more for convenience than security: it's secure but quicker than a pattern or code). The camera is about as good as you'll find, though there are a few specific camera-phones out there with better features. Battery life is one of the most important things to me, and the standard battery with normal usage is excellent; the best of current flagships excluding the Motorola Droid Maxx, and the power saving options allow you to bring the usage down so low as to get several days on a charge (if you use it only for calling and messaging, like your old flip phone). I have absolutely no complaints so far.

I recently upgraded from a Galaxy S3 to the Galaxy S5. There were several key improvements that made the switch worthwhile.
reviewTitle: S3 to S5: nice upgrade! UPDATE.

reviewText: 1. Waterproofing. I'm a photojournalist and occasionally get caught in the rain. I'm reassured that my expensive phone won't get trashed even if I get soggy as a flounder. Also, do you know how many people drop their phones in toilets, pools or puddles? It's a LOT! You need to seal the charging port with an annoying little flap at the bottom, though, which makes finding a desktop charging cradle problematic.

2. Larger / better screen. I'm a big guy and really like a decent-sized phone. Plus I use Google Maps while driving so a tiny screen just doesn't cut it. The S5 screen is slightly larger and sharper than the excellent S3 screen; great for reading eBooks and watching movies and useable even in daylight.

3. Astonishing battery life! When I first bought the S5, I was lucky to get a full day off a charge. But in September there was a big firmware update (4.4.4--now 5.0 Lollipop) which increased the battery life dramatically! I leave just about everything running, yet an astonishing 80-90% battery power remains after 14 hours!

Furthermore the new "Ultra Power Saving Mode" is an emergency option that shuts down all but the basic communication functions while extending the last gasp of battery life for DAYS. This could be a literal life saver.
The S5 charges faster with its new USB 3 charger, but it also charges with standard legacy USB 2 chargers. No funky adapter needed; REALLY nice engineering tweak!
4. Camera. The camera in the new S5 is far better than the S3's camera. I was startled at its quality and ability to shoot under low light.
reviewTitle: quicker than my macbook, a little disappointing in the ...

reviewText: 5. Snappy operation / Using Verizon. The new processor makes the S5 a bit snappier than the S3. Sometimes I use Verizon's Mobile Office to link my laptop to the internet when working in the field. Verizon is awfully expensive, but they have a superior system, especially during emergencies like hurricanes and power outages. Lesson verified during Ike and Katrina.
CONS:
What can I say about this awesome, awesome phone?  I upgraded from a Droid RAZR Maxx.  This thing flies in comparison.  Still learning the ropes, but love it so far.

Purchased a S5 on 7/23/14 through Verizon Wireless and it had one problem after another.  In the first few days, it took three Verizon Wireless Customer Service Reps to set up the email functions.  Ironically, the primary email was a Verizon email address.  None of the Reps considered the set up to be a "hardware" issue.  I discussed replacing this Samsung with a new unit, but they asked me to try more solutions.  Then on the 16th day, two days after the 14-day return policy expired, the phone failed so completely that it could not make calls or text messages.  Finally on the 17th day after the purchase, Verizon acknowledged that it was a hardware problem and agreed to replace it with a refurbished unit.  I asked for a different model or a brand new unit, the Verizon Rep denied the request because the "return" was made a couple days after the 14-day return policy based on the arrangement with Samsung, and they had too much inventory on Samsung S5 to offer another brand.  The Rep did not consider the first three technical calls to be "hardware" related, even though email had been working perfectly fine on the old Motorola phone just an hour before switching to Samsung.  Everyone of the Reps blamed the issues with the third party app developer not working properly with Android devices.  They alluded that Facebook, Yelp, and many other popular apps would "interfere" with the performance of the phone.  The phone was bad to start with, Verizon service made the experience even worse.  Please explore other options when consider buying this phone.  I will switch to another wireless carrier the first opportunity.

My previous phone was a Samsung S2, which I really liked & intended on keeping, but the charger port went bad and it would do all sorts of bizarre things, including drain the battery in 2 hours.  So I took the plunge.  This is a great phone, but here's the beef & why I didn't give it 5 stars...  ATT is why.  I'm not singling ATT out for any particular reason other than the deceptive way they treat customers.  The price you will be quoted here on Amazon is NOT the price you will actually pay.  They warn you there are other fees, but will not tell you what they are other than the $40.00 initiation fee.  Well, people, there are so many fees you'll pay a huge amount over the online quote.  And the $80.00 a month charge for the 2 gig mobile sharing plan listed here is likewise not really what it's going to cost you.  All those unlisted fees and surcharges will cost you $94.88 in the end, almost $15.00 a month, or $180.00 per year, over what you thought you were signing up for.  This has gotta stop.  Won't one of you politicians submit a bill requiring service providers to tell you up front EXACTLY what all the charges are going to be?  This is like living in the Ukraine.
reviewTitle: Very Fast, Wish These Came With Owners Manual...

reviewText: That said, the S5 is a great phone.  More bells & whistles than you can ever use.  Samsung, why can't you pre-load all your phones with a pdf of the owners manual?  That shouldn't add hardly anything to the cost & would really help your customer base.  For the uninitiated, these phones come without directions, so you'd better have a PC at home so you can go to Samsung's website to see how to install the SIM & memory card, 'cause the included Quick Start Guide doesn't tell you that important procedure.

The camera is a fantastic improvement over the S2.  Much clearer and many cool options, but a digital camera will take much better pictures, so don't expect miracles here.  The size of the lens does matter, so while the marketing data on the camera has impressive numbers, my 1994 Canon 4 meg digital camera takes exponentially clearer pictures than this phone.  It's all in the lens.

The phone is really thin.  Take an S2, make it thinner, stretch it vertically, and you have the S5.  Some complain it feels cheap.  Really?  Not to me.  It's light, thin, and compact.  Considering what this phone does, I'm impressed with it's diminutive size & weight.  One change that I'm finding difficult adjusting to are the Home & Back buttons, and the new one on the left you press to dispaly which apps were recently in use.  This last one is really handy, as we all tend to use mostly the same handful of apps, and this is a really quick way to open them up.

The battery life is wonderful.  A charge lasts me about 2 days with substantial use.  The battery is about a third larger than in the S2, charges very quickly thanks to the higher tech charging plug, and even still accepts the old version of a mini usb port charger so in a pinch you can still use your old charging cables, especially if you have a car charger.  I really like that.

So, here's an honest review; I don't know if I got a bad unit or not, but I didn't care enough to have it replaced; I just sold it at a loss.  Let's get the obvious out of the way; the design and materials on this thing are terrible.  The camera bulges out, and if you don't put this sucker in a case, you are going to scratch up the glass.  The whole unit looks like it was designed by fisher price; perhaps I'm a bit spoiled, coming from an iPhone, but c'mon, even that fake metal ring around the phone looks cheap.  The flap for the charger takes some getting used to; start growing long nails!  But if you are willing to overlook the design, the real kicker is the touchwiz monstrosity that is preload on this phone.  If you are used to a consistent user experience, well, it got up and left the building, and brought all his friends with it.  Colors, circles, squares, ripples, oh my!  I have a pity on a fool that opens up the settings menu!  Endless sea of circle icons!  This is the most complex UI I've ever used!  But on the other hand, one might say, it has the horsepower to chew through all those layers of gummy bear UI, right?  Wrong!  Touchwiz stutters, lags, and sometimes crashes and restarts; watching Netflix heats up the phone enough for you to cook eggs on!  That brings me to another topic; battery life.  I can't relate to any of the glowing reviews on here about battery life, but the battery life on this thing lasts for 8 hours; on stand by.  Yeah, there are no rouge processes running in the background, the signal strength is OK, and yet, by 3pm, I have about 30% battery left, and when I get home, the phone is dead.  I'm now tied to a charger everywhere I go; I have one at home, at work, and 2 in the car, just in case I get stranded somewhere and one of the chargers breaks.  Also, the unit does have some physical defects, the front facing camera wasn't seated properly, and there is a small piece of plastic covering the top portion of it.  Whenever I try to do a Skype or the likes, the other person enjoys the view of my neck.  I would assume this is a defect or a phone for ugly people; I don't know!  The device also fails at basic phone functionality too; whenever I receive a call, sometimes the screen would remain dark.  I would wait 1 ring, 2 rings, 3 rings, I would tap the screen a couple of times, shake the device in a voodoo fashion, hit the power button, and then eventually the screen would turn on, and inform me that I missed the call.  Hmm...  One would think that these reasons are enough to avoid this device at all costs, but it's not over yet.  Bluetooth stack on this thing was probably written by a 6 year old; it doesn't work!  It's Snap, Crackle and Pop all the way to the magic forest, with occasional Bluetooth crash here and there.  At first I though it was incompatibility, but then I realized, it's the same with any Bluetooth device.  It made Bluetooth audio useless with this device!  I couldn’t list to music in the car, in the house; my only other option was to run an audio wire, circa 1970’s.  The speakerphone is on the back of the phone and is tinny; crank it up during a conference call, and it starts to crackle.  But it’s not all gloom and doom; perhaps a device can be forgiven for all its innumerable flaws, once you gaze upon the gorgeous AMOLED screen!  It is truly a sight to see, no doubt about it.  This is perhaps, the only advantage that this phone has going for it; this, and the camera.  It does take good-looking shots, whether indoors or out, so you aren’t going to be disappointed by the pictures you take.  Overall, it’s hard to recommend this device over something like an iPhone, or an HTC One; heck even Xperia Z2 is eons ahead of Samsung!  If it weren’t for that screen, this phone would have flopped!

The Galaxy S5 is a good phone, but I'll never buy another Samsung product. About 4 months after I bought it, the charger quit working. I called Samsung for a warranty replacement. I have registered the phone with Samsung, but the agent didn't have the information, so I had to end the call, remove the battery, and find the IMEI number in tiny script (magnifying glass). After putting me on hold for a couple minutes, she told me that I would have to send the charger to them with the receipt. They would evaluate it to be sure there was no damage, and then send me another. This would take up to 11 days. Happily, I have the charger from my previous phone. If I didn't, my phone would be useless for that time without a charger. Looks like Samsung's main concern is that I might be ripping them off.

reviewText: As much as I am over Apple and iTunes, I gotta hand it to them. The OS we beautifully simple and bug free. Unlike Samsung Andriod.

In the past several weeks, we've used the Samsung Galaxy S5 in Black and Electric Blue as well as the HTC One M8.  The HTC audio wins hands down as does its basic appearance, but the Samsung phones are also great.  This black phone is more of a dark gray than true black and the entire case is plastic, giving it a cheaper appearance.  I love the Electric Blue color, but since all phones are protected by case covers, the rears are not visible anyway.  Unlike the HTC, this one offers a removable battery, which along with its superior camera, are why we purchased a pair of these on Verizon Wireless.  The phone arrives loaded with apps which are unnecessary and not wanted, so what we could easily remove, we did.  The Health app is used daily by my daughter, I'm not as diligent myself.  A weakness of this phone, particularly as compared to the HTC, is the rear speaker which muffles the audio while the phone is resting.  I've found that by keeping it face down, it's easier to hear.  The fingerprint security option hasn't worked well for either of us, so it's not currently being used.  Samsung uses its own power port, think of a conjoined USB with a smaller twin port, the same as the Samsung tablet.  In general, this is a really good phone which I expect will last the two years of our contract.
